title: Patriots’ Mack Hollins shows up in shackles, honors Mike Vrabel with separate Super Bowl outfit
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mack Hollins arrived at Super Bowl LX in a jumpsuit with handcuffs and ankle shackles, styled after Hannibal Lecter.
Hollins honored Coach Mike Vrabel by wearing his high school jersey during pregame warmups at Levi's Stadium.
Mike Vrabel arrived in Santa Clara wearing a Hawaiian lei, a gift from Khyiris Tonga's family to support the team.

title: The Celtics had their worst shooting night in years in loss to Jalen Brunson, Knicks: 7 takeaways
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: The Boston Celtics suffered a 111-89 loss to the Knicks with a season-low 17.1% from 3-point range.
Nikola Vučević struggled defensively and scored 11 points on 13 attempts in his second game with the Celtics.
Jaylen Brown's elbows caused foul incidents, but he finished with 26 points and four assists against the Knicks.

title: Why Mike Vrabel played U2 before Patriots’ final Super Bowl meeting
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel played U2's 'Beautiful Day' to motivate the Patriots before Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks.
Patriots head coach Vrabel connected the song to their unexpected victory in Super Bowl XXXVI over the Rams.
Vrabel emphasized 'Belief, Identity, Rage' as key points in his pregame message for the underdog Patriots.

title: ‘You guys got it wrong’: Rodney Harrison calls out Tony Dungy over Bill Belichick Hall of Fame snub
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Rodney Harrison criticized Tony Dungy over Bill Belichick not being elected a first-ballot Hall of Famer.
Tony Dungy declined to reveal his vote, citing Hall of Fame rules, but supported the voting process outcome.
Dungy blamed a recent rule change for Belichick and Robert Kraft not getting inducted into the Hall of Fame.

title: Jordon Hudson takes shot at Robert Kraft with controversial T-shirt
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Jordon Hudson wore an 'Orchids of Asia' shirt at the UNC-Duke game with Bill Belichick.
The shirt references the spa linked to a 2019 prostitution sting involving Robert Kraft.
Kraft was charged but not convicted in the sting, with charges dropped in 2020.

title: Patriots Super Bowl LX live updates: Can Pats beat Seahawks to clinch title?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots aim for their seventh Super Bowl title against the Seahawks at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara.
Receiver Mack Hollins recovers from a lacerated spleen to play in Super Bowl LX for the Patriots.
Mike Vrabel prepares Patriots with a motivational message, invoking Super Bowl XXXVI's underdog victory.

title: Holy Cross dedicates court to Bob Cousy
author: Trevor Hass
bullets: Holy Cross named its home court 'Bob Cousy ’50 Court' in honor of the Celtics legend and 1947 NCAA champion.
The dedication ceremony, attended by 97-year-old Cousy, was held during a game where Holy Cross beat Lehigh 76-67.
Bill Simmons, Charlie Baker, and Karen Kenyatta Russell attended the event at the Luth Athletic Complex in Worcester.

title: Healey proposes eliminating statute of limitations for rape when DNA evidence exists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Governor Healey proposes removing the 15-year statute of limitations for rape cases in Massachusetts when DNA evidence is present.
The proposal requires sexual assault evidence kits to be stored for at least 15 years and tested within 30 days.
The plan is part of Healey's broader efforts to combat sex crimes, including a five-year initiative to address sex trafficking.

title: Watch: Patriots share hype video ahead of Super Bowl LX
author: Trevor Hass
bullets: The New England Patriots released a hype video ahead of their Super Bowl LX matchup against the Seattle Seahawks.
Head coach Mike Vrabel emphasizes building a proud program and maximizing player potential in the team's hype video.
Patriots wide receiver Stefon Diggs motivates teammates, stating, 'Ain't nobody like us,' in the video.

title: Former employee at Mass. post office pleads guilty after secretly recording female co-workers
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Nicholas Testagrossa, 43, pleaded guilty to video voyeurism and obstruction after secretly recording female co-workers at a Westminster post office.
Testagrossa placed hidden cameras in the women's restroom, capturing videos in February and March 2025, officials said.
He faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for obstruction, with sentencing scheduled for May 12, 2026.
